bibl.title: Letter from George H. Torney to the Director of the Yellow Fever Bureau, December 7, 1912

div1.p: Torney reports that Agramonte has requested that a statement published in the Yellow Fever Bureau Bulletin be corrected. Torney explains how he believes the apparent injustice occurred, and requests the correction on behalf of the Office of the Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from George H. Torney to the Director of the Yellow Fever Bureau, December 7, 1912
div1.opener:
Letter of Gen. H Torney Surgeon Gen. US Army, to Director, yellow fever Bureau
Dec 7, 1912. Original in NY Public Library
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
38657-12.
December 7, 1912.
Director, Yellow Fever Bureau,
Liverpool, England.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Professor Aristides Agramonte of the University of Havana, Cuba,
formerly a member of the U. S. Commission headed by Major Walter Reed,
which demonstrated the transmission of yellow fever by the agency of the
Stegomyia mosquito, has called the attention of this office to a statement
on page 92 of the Yellow Fever Bureau Bulletin, Vol. II, No. 1, which says:

“Again, Agramonte claims equal credit with the other members of the
Commission, but according to various authors, did not take part in the
first series of mosquito transmission experiments, nor was he even in-
formed of their being carried out (Compilation, pp. 16 and 21; Janus p. 64).”

Professor Agramonte requests that this statement be corrected by this
office as it appeared in an official publication which emanated from this
office, and does his share in the work of the Army Board great injustice.

Chapters 2 and 3 of the Compilation, “Yellow Fever, Senate Document
No. 822,” were both prepared by my assistant, Lieut. Colonel J. R. Kean,
Medical Corps, in response to special demands and with some haste. Chap-
ter 2 was prepared as part of a statement made to Congress in order to se-
cure a pension for the widow of Major Walter Reed, and Chapter 3 was, as
shown by the note of transmission prepared in response to a call by the
President of the United States showing not the full scientific work of
the board but the part taken in the yellow fever experiments which involv-
ed personal risk and which on that account called especially for a reward
from Congress. In stating that Dr. Agramonte did not share in the dangers
-2-
of exposure to yellow fever because he was a Cuban and immune to that dis-
ease, the writer had no desire or intention to minimize the very important
share of the scientific work of the Commission which was delegated to Dr.
Agramonte. On account of Dr. Agramonte's distance from Washington there
was no time or opportunity for him to review and correct the statements
made with regard to his connection with the matter, and the assertion made
on page 21 that he was not cognizant of the first series of experiments was
accepted upon an authority which seemed at that time to be satisfactory,
but which is now shown to be incorrect by the statement of Dr. Agramonte,
a copy of which is enclosed.

The enclosed statement was prepared by Dr. Agramonte at the sugges-
tion of the Surgeon General of the Army and placed on file in this office
for the purpose of forming a basis for the correction of any injustice
which may have been done Dr. Agramonte in the preceding publications re-
ferred to. His statements are in the opinion of this office entitled to
full credence.
A copy of this letter has been furnished to Dr. Agramonte.
div1.closer: Very respectfully, Geo. H. Torney, Surgeon General, U. S. Army.
